clinical_study.brief_title: Sorry Not Sorry: Apologizing and Its Effect on Discomfort During Dressing Removal
clinical_study.official_title: Sorry Not Sorry: Apologizing and Its Effect on Discomfort During Dressing Removal

brief_summary.textblock: Use of dressing is common place following surgery, allowing for wounds to be covered and protected. Dressing material with adhesive contact layers or adhesive tape is integral to sealing off the wound. Mechanical stripping of stratum corneum during dressing removal causes pain and discomfort. During dressing removal, practitioners may at times apologize as a function of empathy. Previous study investigated speed of dressing removal and its effect on discomfort during dressing change. In this study, the investigators aim to investigate how empathy expressed in form of saying "sorry" affect the perception of pain during dressing change?

primary_outcome.description: Based on self reported 10 point visual analog scale

arm_group.description: A small strip of self-adhesive dressing (3cm by 4cm) will be applied to the back of the patients' participants' hand and side of neck. After one minute of acclimatization, the dressing will be removed by the examiner. During the removal, the examiner will say sorry repeatedly. Following the dressing removal, participant will rate their pain with a 10 point visual analog scale.

A small strip of self-adhesive dressing (3cm by 4cm) will be applied to the back of the patients' participants' hand and side of neck. After one minute of acclimatization, the dressing will be removed by the examiner. During the removal, the examiner will remain silent. Following the dressing removal, participant will rate their pain with a 10 point visual analog scale.

intervention.description: The objective of this study is to investigate how empathy expressed in form of saying "sorry" affect the perception of pain during dressing change?

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy adult volunteers, age >18.
Exclusion Criteria:
- individuals with sensitivity to tape or dressing, anxiety disorders, or pain syndromes.
